newsitem.title: UK: Fleming American settles $85mln suit for $4.0 mln.
newsitem.headline: Fleming American settles $85mln suit for $4.0 mln.

text.p: Fleming American Investment Trust Plc said it will pay $4.0 million to settle a $85 million environment suit, which arose from a creosote plant built in the 1800s.

"It seems incredible that a British company can be sued by the U.S. EPA for something that happened nearly 100 years ago, when no laws were broken at the time," Fleming American's chairman Julian Saunders said in a statement.
Fleming American was sued by the Environmental Protection Agency and Louisana state over land pollution by a creosote plant owned by a company that later formed the London-listed investment trust.
The allegations related to actions of the Alabama, New Orleans, Texas and Pacific Junction Railways Co and New Orleans and North Eastern Railroad from 1882 to 1902.
The trust said it hoped the 250,000 pounds in legal fees spent to defend the action would be regarded by shareholders as "justified by the outcome".
The action has overshadowed the trust's share performance. It was trading at a discount of 22 percent to value of underlying assets due to the action, which began in October 1995.
In response to the settlement, in which Fleming American admitted no liability, shares in the trust rose 19 pence to 368 pence by the close of trade in London.
